full_title_en: Winters' Formula for Metabolic Acidosis Compensation
medium_description_en: Calculates the expected pCO₂ compensation in a purely metabolic acidosis.
short_description_en: Expected pCO₂ if pure metabolic acidosis.

seo.meta_description_en: The Winters’ Formula for Metabolic Acidosis Compensation Calculates the expected pCO<sub>2</sub> compensation in a purely metabolic acidosis

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• A patient with a suspect pure metabolic acidosis.
  • A patient with a mixed acidosis to determine level of compensation.
how_to_use.why_use_en: In a compensated state, a patient with a metabolic acidosis should be able to compensate by developing a respiratory alkalosis. Winters' Formula predicts this level of “appropriate” compensation.

next_steps.advice_en:
• Users may be interested in the MDCalc ABG Analyzer which can attempt to assess for different forms of acid-base disorders.
  • The Anion Gap calculator can also help determine the type of acidosis (gap vs non-gap).

about.formula_en:
Expected pCO₂ = 1.5 x HCO3- + 8 ± 2

Note: although the original Winters formula used a standard error of ±2, newer data suggest that pCO₂ may vary up to ±5 (Adrogué and Madias 2010).

Original/Primary Reference.text: Albert MS, Dell RB, Winters RW. Quantitative Displacement of Acid-Base Equilibrium in Metabolic Acidosis. Ann Intern Med. 1967;66:312-322. doi:10.7326/0003-4819-66-2-312.

Other References.text: Adrogué HJ, Madias NE. Secondary responses to altered acid-base status: the rules of engagement. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2010;21(6):920-3.

Validation.text: Asch MJ, Dell RB, Williams GS, Cohen M, Winters RW. Time course for development of respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis. J Lab Clin Med. 1969 Apr;73(4):610-5.

creator_info.about_en: August Supervia, MD, is a practicing physician in the emergency department at Hospital Universitari del Mar in Barcelona, Spain. He is an active researcher and a member of the European Respiratory Society.
